The name vi is derived from the shortest unambiguous abbreviation for the command visual .     From the UNIX system prompt, you start up vi by typing   vi filename   This will open a file called filename . If a file of that name does not already exist, it starts a new one. Vi has a command mode and an insert (or "editing") mode. You are, initially, always in command mode. The a and i commands (see below) will put you in editing mode. The escape key takes you out of editing mode and puts you back in command mode.   Unless otherwise noted, enter the following commands by simply typing them. (That is, you do not need to press the Return key.) Commands should be typed in lowercase letters, unless otherwise indicated. The current line refers to the line on which your cursor is placed. You start out in command mode.        To Go into Editing Mode  Command Description   a (once)   For "append". Puts you in insert (or "editing") mode. Any characters that you type subsequently will be added to your file to the right of your cursor.       i (once) For "insert". Puts you in editing mode (if you are in command mode); characters that you type subsequently will be inserted to the left of your cursor.  <Return> The Return key. Starts a new line (if you are in editing mode).  <Esc> The Esc key. Takes you out of insert (or "editing") mode and returns you to command mode.      To Use in Command Mode  Command Description   h (or ←) Moves your cursor one character to the left.  j (or ↓) Moves your cursor down one line.  k (or ↑) Moves your cursor up one line.  l (or →) Moves your cursor one character to the right.  ^f Scroll forward one screenful.  ^b Scroll backward one screenful.  x Deletes the character on which your cursor lies.  dd   Deletes the current line.  u Undoes your last command.  J Joins the next line with the current line.  ZZ Save your work and quit vi.  :w <Return> Writes (saves) your changes. (Typed sequentially.)  :wq <Return> Saves your changes and quits vi. (Typed sequentially.)  :q! <Return> Quits vi without saving your changes. (Typed sequentially.)                      Need Assistance?     Please send any questions to: webteam@nyu.edu     Note:  Many of the resources in this guide are specific to the main (non-CMS) NYU Web server, www.nyu.edu, accessed through an account on the i4.nyu.edu machine. If you have questions about a site that is not on this server, please contact your school's webmaster or write to webteam@nyu.edu for more information. CTS 2015 | Critical Tourism Studies Conference VI                                                                                                                              CTS 2015        Critical Tourism Studies Conference VI                              Search for:                                       Skip to content          Home   Call for Papers      Tourism Analysis Special Issue       Destination and venue      How to get there       Keynote speakers   About CTS   Register                                                                                     CTS is 10 years old!                September 29, 2014 January 28, 2015  Lynn                      10 years CTS: Reflections on the road less travelled and the journey ahead     Critical Tourism Studies has come a long way since its first conference in Dubrovnik in 2005. From June 26th until 30th 2015 , we will celebrate our 10th anniversary in Opatija, Croatia . We welcome you to join us, reflect on the road that we have travelled, celebrate, and reflect on where the future lies for a continued ‘critical turn’ in tourism studies.                                                                                                                    by                                                                    How to get there                February 1, 2015 April 28, 2015  Lynn                      Hello to all CTS’ers !     We are hoping you are counting down to the June conference as much as we are.   A few delegates have asked us about transport arrangements to Opatija, so we thought we would put this blog post together with the best flight options.     The closest airport to Opatija is Rijeka . There are direct flights from BERLIN – BERN – BRUSSELS (CHARLEROI)- COPENHAGEN – DUBROVNIK – DUSSELDORF – FRANKFURT – HAMBURG – HELSINKI – INNSBRUCK – KOLN – KOŠICE – LONDON (HEATHROW, STANSTED) – MALTA – MOSCOW – MUNICH – OSIJEK – OSLO –OSLO (RYGGE) – RIGA – SPLIT -STOCKHOLM (SKAVSKA)- STUTTGART – VILNIUS – TALINN – ZAGREB.    We recommend this airport to our delegates, because there is a fast and very affordable bus service to Opatija (€10 per person). The bus stop is 2 minutes from the hotel.   Other options are the airports of Pula (1 hour), Trieste (Italy, 1.5 hours), Ljubljana (Slovenia, 1 hour 45 minutes) and Zagreb (2 hours).   We will be offering transfers from these airports to the Ambasador Hotel, to be paid in cash on site. The prices are listed below:          Airport    Car 1-3 places   Mini-van 3-8 places        PULA    85,00 €    160,00 €        ZAGREB    120,00 €    144,00 €        LJUBLJANA    140,00 €    186,00 €        TRIESTE    120,00 €    156,00 €           We have larger buses available too for groups over 8 people – those can bring the price per person down even further.   To get the best value, we will try to group delegates arriving at the same airport into one transfer. If you would like to make use of this service, please complete the form below:   https://nyu.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_5yUcz14OOjh4Map   A bus service is also available from Zagreb airport to Rijeka and tickets can be bought here:   http://www.plesoprijevoz.hr/   The bus departs at 3.30 pm, and from Rijeka it is an easy taxi ride to Opatija or you can take bus number 32.   If you have any questions we can help with, just let us know!   Best wishes,   The CTS team              by                                                                             Our sponsor                Questions about getting to Opatija?
